title: Fox News boss Lachlan Murdoch bemoans the absence of 'civil debate' days after Shepard Smith exit
text:
Lachlan Murdoch is addressing the 'nasty' environment at Fox News in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter.

The current head of the network, who appears on the annual THR 100 alongside dad Rupert was asked about how he dealt with unhappy employees and fighting among staff.

'Look, I think unfortunately in this country, there is less and less civil debate, and I think we're all poorer for it,' said Lachlan.

Scroll down for video

Murdoch he write: 'Look, I think unfortunately in this country, there is less and less civil debate, and I think we're all poorer for it,' said Lachlan Murdoch (above in July)

Tuck it: On Friday, Shepard Smith (left) left Fox News after 24 years following comments made by Tucker Carlson (right) on his primetime program

He made the comment despite the fact that Shepard Smith recently exited Fox News in the wake of remarks made by Tucker Carlson, who mocked the news host on-air by affecting his speech.

Carlson did this in response to Smith criticizing a guest who called their co-worker, Judge Andrew Napolitano, a 'fool' on Tucker Carlson Tonight.

Reports emerged in the wake of Smith's departure claiming that Fox News executives ultimately sided with Carlson on the matter.

A network spokesperson denied this and said: 'At no time did anyone - including anyone in management or a third party - speak to Shepard Smith regarding this matter. Anything to the contrary is entirely false and wildly inaccurate.'

Multiple sources have told DailyMail.com that Smith was unhappy with how executives dealt with the situation, and felt that Carlson and the other primetime hosts were allowed to get away with this kind of behavior because they were pundits.

He on the other hand was told not to disparage Carlson and Laura Ingraham, because he was a news anchor.

Smith is not the only person to have issues at Fox, with Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane also speaking out against the news network on multiple occasions.

MacFarlane also took a role in the recent Showtime series The Loudest Voice in the Room, which took a look at sexual misconduct at Fox News while the network was under the control of Roger Ailes.

When asked how 'awkward' it was to deal with those dissenting voices, Lachlan said: 'I don't think it's awkward at all, actually. We've never steered any creator to have a political bent or to influence what they put on our air.'

And, as is the case in all Murdoch interviews these days, there was also the questions about a few current television and theatrical productions.

'There's Succession, Ink on Broadway, then The Loudest Voice and Bombshell about Fox News,' pointed out the reporter interviewing Lachlan.

That's four separate projects this year that are either about your family business or a veiled story about your family. Why do you think people are so interested now?

'Well, I'm not sure they're all about our family. But people are searching for good storylines,' said Lachlan.

'I think a lot of these are more fictional than they are reality, but, you know, that's up to writers and producers to decide.'
